newsitem.title: GERMANY: Suspected Kurdish PKK leader arrested in Germany.
newsitem.headline: Suspected Kurdish PKK leader arrested in Germany.

text.p: German authorities said on Thursday they had arrested a man suspected of being a leading member of the outlawed Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) and of organising attacks as part of its campaign for autonomy from Turkey.

The Federal Prosecutor's Office said the Kurd, whom it identified only as Nasir C., was suspected of being "a member of a terrorist organisation" and of ordering arson attacks and destruction of Turkish property in Germany.

Prosecutors said the 23-year-old led the PKK's north German division from 1992 until February 1994, when he took over the European leadership of the Berlin-based Kurdish Intellectual Association, closely linked to the PKK.
Germany banned the PKK after a spectacular spate of attacks on Turkish properties across Germany and Europe in 1993.

Prosecutors said Nasir C., detained in Berlin on April 1 and formally placed under arrest on Wednesday, had organised two series of attacks in 1993 on Turkish property, including a social club, banks, airline firms and travel agencies.
More than 22,000 people have died over the past 12 years in the guerrilla war against Turkish rule which the PKK is waging in eastern Turkey.
Tens of thousands of troops, backed by air power, have been sweeping the region in a spring offensive against the rebels since last weekend. Security officials said 43 rebels had been killed so far.
